text: toad endless night
hi everyone
anthony fantano here
internet's busiest music nerd gonna do a
review here of the new toad
album endless knight toad a phoenix rock
band this is their latest
album mini album sort of though this
release is pretty short doesn't even hit
that 30 minute mark it is a pretty
powerful piece of rock music now these
guys even though their name is towed in
great big fat capital letters it's
actually an acronym for takeover and
destroy which is actually a pretty
badass name and as much as i love
hearing something extraordinarily
fast heavy melodic or
moving being well-rounded in all of
these things is is kind of a quality
that is overlooked at times especially
on the more extreme side of music
however endless knight takes all these
things into account across its five song
track list it's a group of songs that
work in multiple layers crushing heavy
rifts that occasionally play slow are
fast at times especially when the band
is going down a more black metal road
with the blast beat drumming but a lot
of the time you're going to find this lp
to going at kind of a mid pace a lot of
the grooves that these riffs are playing
have a bit of a heavy metal vibe to them
or maybe even some rock and roll swagger
there's some organ and and synth keys
that feel kind of retro throughout this
lp as well really kind of bringing an
occult vibe to the table and on top of
all of that takeover and destroy has a
pretty strong sense of melody too
melodies that are dark and are sinister
and romanticized again pulling from that
very clear black metal influence
throughout these songs
which also plays out in the blast beats
that i mentioned tremolo pic guitars and
some vocals that are really really
ferocious bloody raw
sometimes blending elements of black
metal and death metal it's a really
seamless blend at times of these extreme
and not so extreme rock styles and
really when i think of all the genres
that influence takeover and destroy i
really am reminded of color talk however
takeover and destroy comes to a very
different musical conclusion as they
feel much darker and i feel have a
little bit more finesse at times like
the very chilling pianos and hellish
melodies that play at the title track on
this lp even though the very crushing
guitar riffs that come in after this
intro change the vibe a lot images of of
candles and pentagrams and hooded cloaks
and demons all of this is sort of still
at the core of takeover and destroys
music and they continue to emphasize
this vibe when the songs get heavier
with some harmonized guitar leads some
very sort of deadpan background vocals
or even some very morbid lyricism which
at times can be kind of cosmic and
otherworldly really this lp feels like a
sort of short soundtrack to a very
devilish
ritual and hooks on this lp can be kind
of catchy as well especially with how
ferocious and just over the top the
vocals can be and i'm also digging how
when
toad attempts to stretch some of these
songs out past the six minute mark there
are some successes as well with some
really climactic builds of harmonious
guitars and synthesizers which make for
a pretty haunting contrast from the
pummeling riffs they usually back up
most of the verses on this lp now i love
the ambition that makes toad write some
of these longer songs or just in general
write multi-phased songs but
occasionally it doesn't go over
amazingly like on the intro track from
this lp as well as the second track
where i feel like some of the slower
moments instantaneously just bust right
back into the heavier spots kind of
ruining or not even really fully
appreciating the tension that these
slower spots had built up to this point
still the latter half of this lp is
pretty solid the third track howling
house is pretty interesting in its
transitions it has this six eight intro
breaks into these four four blast beats
goes back into the six eight on the
latter part of the track over these six
eight time signatures bringing some
really moody guitar leads the song
boundaries of flesh has some fast and
sludgy riffs that remind me of some of
the more intense moments from high on
fire's last full-length lp but also
brings in some cleanly sung and eerie
vocals on the second half of the song
that work pretty nicely and as far as
the closing track goes on this thing
maybe one of the more cohesive songs on
this thing with this very slow intro a
lot of heavy metal guitar heroism going
on in the middle of the song and then
the very end just building up to this
huge climactic finish
overall i dug this lp a lot it's loud
it's heavy it's destructive it's
memorable with the vocals and melodies
just burning just on fire throughout
this thing however i did end up kind of
wanting
more material more length from not only
some of these songs but just this album
in general and and i guess if there is
one more thing that kind of hinders this
lp for me it's that there is kind of a
sameness that runs across many of these
tracks in terms of some of the vocal
deliveries or just the sound and the
vibe of these riffs and it is a positive
in that it makes this lp feel really
cohesive and maybe even conceptual in a
sense but then again there is kind of a
stagnation to that as well i'm feeling a
decent to strong seven on this thing if
you've given them a listen what did you
think did you love it hate it why
what do you think i should review next
and that's it this review was my opinion
if you don't like it here's a straw i
want to give a shout out to friends
family god country and apple pie
only the strong subscribe all mistakes
were intentional
anthony fantano
toad
forever
[Music]
